author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Review: ‘A Commercial Jingle for Regina Comet’ Is Missing a Few Notes
description: In this new musical, a singer’s future hangs on one song, but entrusting it to an inexperienced songwriting team is not, perhaps, the shrewdest choice.
content: Once upon a time, Regina Comet was a pop star who filled arenas. Now that her career desperately needs a reboot, she and her team have a brilliant idea: They will come out with a perfume — sorry, a fragrance, called Relevance — and peg her comeback to it. Because of course listeners will just follow that scent all the way to Regina’s big concert.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: Biden Is Taking a Page Out of Trump’s Immigration Playbook
description: The president promised a “humane” immigration policy. Images of U.S. agents menacing Haitians at the border tell a different story.
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: A Would-Be Mayor Wants Advice. Who’s He Going to Call?
description: Incoming New York mayors tend not to ask their predecessors for advice. Eric Adams, the likely next mayor, is an exception.
content: It’s Tuesday. We’ll look at the relationship between Eric Adams, the Democratic mayoral nominee in New York City, and one of his predecessors. We’ll also look at someone who has five reasons to hope that today’s weather forecast is wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: With his reappointment on the line, Elizabeth Warren calls Jerome Powell ‘a dangerous man.’
description: Other Democrats fretted about diversity at the Federal Reserve as Chair Jerome H. Powell testified ahead of an imminent personnel shake-up.
content: Senator Elizabeth Warren, Democrat of Massachusetts, blasted the Federal Reserve chair, Jerome H. Powell, for his financial regulation track record and said that she would not support him if the White House renominated him, calling him a “dangerous man to head up the Fed.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Serenity Hughes
title: How My Phone’s Most Annoying Feature Saved My Life
description: Voice mail messages from my family allowed me to slowly climb out of a state of gloom and self-imposed isolation.
content: My cousin left this message for me three months into my freshman year of college. His Chicago accent was so thick that I had to replay it a few times: Aye cuz, answer yo phone, he said. I talked to my mom, she told me you are out there doing yo thang. We were kids walking through Hyde Park, dreaming about everything we wanted to do, and you down there making it happen. I’m really proud of you cuz. I love you cuz, stay true to yourself. You’re my motivation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Proudfoot
title: In a Galaxy Far, Far Away, He Was Almost Anakin Skywalker
description: Devon Michael was a rising child actor in the 1990s. Until he auditioned for “Star Wars.”
content: It was the late 1990s, and 3,000 young actors around the world were scouted for the role of a lifetime. On the ride home from school, Devon Michael’s mom told him he’d be auditioning for one of the most anticipated movies ever. “The Phantom Menace” — then the next installment of the “Star Wars” franchise — was in production, and they were searching for young Anakin Skywalker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: We Underestimated Trump Before. It Didn’t Go Well.
description: The former president continues to pose a threat because our political imagination fails us.
content: Sometimes, and much to our detriment, we find real events are simply too outlandish to take seriously.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Asher Elbein
title: The World’s Deadliest Bird Was Raised by People 18,000 Years Ago
description: Researchers studying ancient cassowary egg shells in New Guinea found signs that the sharp-taloned bird was being domesticated.
content: The southern cassowary is often called the world’s most dangerous bird.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold and Melissa Eddy
title: German Election Leaves Merkel’s Conservatives in Disarray
description: Sunday’s defeat has revealed a gasping conservative party. But what that means for Germany’s future is not clear as traditional left-right politics are scrambled.
content: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel was standing two paces behind Armin Laschet, her party’s candidate to succeed her, stony-faced and with her hands clenched.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Wong
title: A Street Vendor Had No Permit. Her Produce Was Tossed in the Trash.
description: In the Bronx, where many go hungry, widely shared videos captured a clash between the authorities and one of thousands of unlicensed vendors.
content: At a busy intersection in the Bronx, two sanitation workers grab whole watermelons and boxes of produce from a street vendor’s stall and toss them into a garbage truck to be crushed as police officers stand by.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere, Shashank Bengali and Noah Weiland
title: Pfizer and BioNTech Submit Data Backing Vaccine for Children 5 to 11
description: The companies said that their vaccine was safe and effective in that age group, and that they would submit a formal request in the coming weeks to U.S. regulators to allow a pediatric dose.
content: WASHINGTON — Pfizer and BioNTech announced on Tuesday that they had submitted data to the Food and Drug Administration that the companies said showed their coronavirus vaccine is safe and effective in children ages 5 to 11.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ligaya Mishan and Anthony Cotsifas
title: What Does It Mean to Eat What You Fear?
description: Throughout history, we’ve tried to conquer what unsettles us by consuming it. The practice raises questions about who the real monsters are.
content: THE BOX JELLYFISH pulses through the water, so translucent it appears more outline than flesh, with its dropped handkerchief of a head and tentacles up to 10 feet long. It has no armor, neither shell nor bone, only those delicate trailing tentacles studded with nematocysts, tiny tubes filled with venom. These are essentially projectiles that “act as a hypodermic delivery device,” explains Angel Yanagihara, a biochemist at the University of Hawaii at Manoa who, after barely surviving a box jellyfish sting 24 years ago, has devoted her career to studying the mechanics of her near killer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: ‘I Feel an Abundance’: A Composer Dips Into the Dance World
description: The choreographer Andrea Miller chose Lido Pimienta — “she’s a superstar” — to score her new piece for New York City Ballet. They talk about breaking new ground.
content: “Arrghh, the pressure!” exclaimed the composer Lido Pimienta, after being told that she and the choreographer Andrea Miller were the first all-female team to be commissioned to create a piece for New York City Ballet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Britain’s Gas Crisis, Explained
description: A shortage of truck drivers has led to empty fuel pumps around the country, creating long lines at gas stations and panic buying.
content: LONDON — Drivers in Britain have been rushing to gas stations to fill up, amid a fuel shortage that has lasted days. Long lines at gas stations and rising fuel prices are the latest challenges that the country faces as it emerges from the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: A 12-Team Playoff Isn’t a Done Deal. Math and History Suggest a ‘Yes’ Looms.
description: If the College Football Playoff field triples, the competition will most likely become more lucrative than the Division I men’s basketball tournament.
content: The rubber stamps stayed packed away on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: What’s New?
description: Meghan Morris makes her New York Times Crossword debut.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to Meghan Morris, who is making her New York Times Crossword debut. As the parade of debuts marches on this month, I am increasingly excited to see where these new constructors will take the art and science of crossword puzzles. What’s new? The 68 constructors who have debuted in 2021, that’s what.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lois Smith Brady
title: Reaching New Heights Together
description: Steph Davis and Ian Mitchard, daredevil sky divers, wingsuit flyers and BASE jumpers, married nearly three years ago. Just two months after their wedding their life changed.
content: Not long before their wedding on Nov. 3, 2018, Ian Mitchard and Steph Davis were sitting in their home in Moab, Utah, talking about death. For them, it was not an uncomfortable or even uncommon conversation. As wingsuit flyers, BASE jumpers and sky divers, they regularly spent more time in the air than some species of birds. The possibility of dying? “It’s in our face all the time,” Mr. Mitchard, now 40, said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: A Brexit-Weary Britain Finds Itself in a New Crisis With Brexit Overtones
description: The government has blamed problems like food shortages on the virus. With the pandemic waning, the focus in the fuel crisis is shifting to Britain’s exit from the E.U.
content: LONDON — Few things are more likely to set teeth on edge in Downing Street than the tentative winner of an inconclusive German election declaring that Brexit is the reason Britons are lining up at gas stations like it’s 1974.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: LeBron James Laughs at Your ‘Old’ Lakers Memes. After His Nap.
description: The Los Angeles Lakers have five players who are at least 35 years old, including the 36-year-old James. Older, wiser, championship?
content: LeBron James has seen the memes and read the punch lines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Davey Alba
title: Facebook groups promoting ivermectin as a Covid-19 treatment continue to flourish.
description: In some of the groups, members are given advice on how to evade the company’s rules on misinformation.
content: Facebook has become more aggressive at enforcing its coronavirus misinformation policies in the past year. But the platform remains a popular destination for people discussing how to acquire and use ivermectin, a drug typically used to treat parasitic worms, even though the Food and Drug Administration has warned people against taking it to treat Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Anna Schaverien
title: A Star-Studded Production
description: Creative Artists Agency’s purchase of rival ICM Partners is the largest consolidation of the talent agency industry in years.
content: Creative Artists Agency is buying its smaller rival, ICM Partners, for an undisclosed amount. It’s the largest industry consolidation in more than a decade, and one that could have significant ripple effects in the worlds of entertainment and sports. While the two agencies have flirted with a deal for some time, they became serious in July, at Allen & Company’s annual media retreat in Sun Valley.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric W. Sanderson
title: Let Water Go Where It Wants to Go
description: Hurricane Ida ravaged places that were once stream beds and wetlands.
content: For more than 20 years, I have been studying the historical ecology of New York City and thinking about what it means for the city’s future, and I can tell you one thing: Water will go where water has always gone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner and David E. Sanger
title: How the Huawei Case Raised Fears of ‘Hostage Diplomacy’ by China
description: Critics of the Justice Department deal to free the Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou say it could blunt tools like sanctions and prosecutions.
content: WASHINGTON — The talks between the Justice Department and a top executive from Huawei Technologies, the Chinese telecommunications giant, had stretched over more than 12 months and two presidential administrations, and boiled down to one overarching dispute: whether Meng Wanzhou, daughter of Huawei’s founder, would admit to any wrongdoing.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Haitians Gamble on U.S. After Trying to Make a Life in Chile
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, September 28, 2021.
content: “People are selling the few things they have and leaving with their children. They say they’d rather die than keep being humiliated here.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: What’s Missing From the Conversation About Systemic Racism
description: Often-cited examples of redlining and police shootings don’t tell such a simple story.
content: “He thinks there’s no systemic racism.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Bringing Aaliyah Into the Streaming Era
description: A conversation about the tug of war over her musical legacy, and how her songs — even without a digital presence — impacted the evolution of contemporary R&B.
content: Music streaming services have become inadvertent and imperfect proxies for the infinite jukebox. But as younger listeners increasingly come to rely on them, missing artist catalogs leave historical holes that are difficult to fill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: How You Can Find Rental Assistance in California
description: The state’s eviction moratorium ends on Thursday.
content: Perhaps it’s a sign that the worst of the coronavirus pandemic is behind us, or that it's stretched on far longer than we ever expected, but two key pandemic-related safety net programs are soon coming to a close.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heidi Julavits
title: Karl Ove Knausgaard’s Touch of Evil
description: “The Morning Star,” his new novel, explores both the uncanny and the mundane.
content: A reviewer for this newspaper, writing about Patricia Lockwood’s 2021 novel, “No One Is Talking About This,” described the author, glowingly, as a “modern word witch,” before settling on this conclusion: “For all the local beauty and humor of ‘No One Is Talking About This,’ it does not feel like a good novel, exactly, because it does not feel like a novel at all. But nowadays, what does?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: TikTok Wants More Ad Dollars, and It Has a New Plan to Get Them
description: In a quest for more revenue, the app known for short videos is trying to make it easier to match its stars with brands.
content: TikTok has an advertising problem. On Tuesday, the company rolled out a new plan to help deal with it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport, Emily Cochrane and Jeanna Smialek
title: Yellen Warns of ‘Catastrophic’ Consequences From Debt Limit Breach
description: The Treasury secretary, testifying alongside Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, implored Congress to raise or suspend the nation’s borrowing cap before an Oct. 18 deadline.
content: WASHINGTON — Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen warned lawmakers on Tuesday of “catastrophic” consequences if Congress failed to raise or suspend the statutory debt limit in less than three weeks, saying inaction could lead to a self-inflicted economic recession and a financial crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Explore the Space Race With The New York Times’s Archive
description: In this extended lesson plan, students will use the Times archive to explore the questions: What was the space race? Who won it? And why did it matter? Then they will connect the past to the current competition for space.
content: Fifty-two years ago, the Apollo 11 crew landed on the moon — the culmination of a decade-long “space race” between the United States and the Soviet Union — widely regarded as one of humanity’s greatest achievements. Today, there is a different kind of race being run, as private companies compete to take ordinary citizens to space, the moon, Mars and beyond.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korea Launches Short-Range Missile as Country’s Envoy Speaks at U.N.
description: The launch came just three days after the sister of North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, said the country would consider holding a meeting with the South and declaring an official end to the Korean War.
content: SEOUL — North Korea fired a short-range missile off its east coast on Tuesday, the South Korean military said, just as the North’s ambassador to the United Nations called on the United States to end joint military exercises and withdraw its strategic weapons from around the Korean Peninsula.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: ‘I Can’t Imagine a Good Future’: Young Iranians Increasingly Want Out
description: Divorce is up, fertility rates are down and many from Iran’s younger generation are postponing weddings and searching for ways to leave the country in the face of economic and political stagnation.
content: TEHRAN — Amir, an engineering master’s student standing outside Tehran University, had thought about going into digital marketing, but worried that Iran’s government would restrict Instagram, as it had other apps. He had considered founding a start-up, but foresaw American sanctions and raging inflation blocking his way.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Cloud Cuckoo Land,’ by Anthony Doerr: An Excerpt
description: An excerpt from “Cloud Cuckoo Land,” by Anthony Doerr
content: He escorts five fifth graders from the elementary school to the public library through curtains of falling snow. He is an octogenarian in a canvas coat; his boots are fastened with Velcro; cartoon penguins skate across his necktie. All day, joy has steadily inflated inside his chest, and now, this afternoon, at 4:30 p.m. on a Thursday in February, watching the children run ahead down the sidewalk— Alex Hess wearing his papier-mâché donkey head, Rachel Wilson carrying a plastic torch, Natalie Hernandez lugging a portable speaker—the feeling threatens to capsize him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne Kaufman
title: The Owner of The Mysterious Bookshop Built His Dream House
description: And of course it includes a two-story library — modeled on the Bodleian at Oxford University — for his massive collection of books.
content: It is a truth universally acknowledged that a man in possession of a good 60,000 books must be in want of a very big house.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Woo
title: How Covid Misinformation Created a Run on Animal Medicine
description: Veterinarians, ranchers and farmers say they are struggling with the effects of the surging demand for ivermectin, a deworming drug.
content: Emerson Animal Hospital was down to its last 10 milliliters of ivermectin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Eleven Madison Park Explores the Plant Kingdom’s Uncanny Valley
description: Now vegan, Daniel Humm’s acclaimed restaurant does strange things to vegetables.
content: The man with the hammer treats everything as a nail, the saying goes. Something like that seems to be afflicting Eleven Madison Park in its new vegan incarnation. The restaurant’s chef and owner, Daniel Humm, is using the skills he brought to meat and seafood to whack away at vegetables.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Murder Charge in Case That Renewed Outrage Over U.K. Women’s Safety
description: Sabina Nessa, 28, was killed in a park in Southeast London. A 36-year-old man has been charged with her murder.
content: LONDON — A 36-year-old man appeared in a British court on Tuesday after being charged with the murder of Sabina Nessa, an elementary-school teacher who was killed in a park near her home in Southeast London earlier this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Man Who Blackmailed Girls to Send Explicit Images Is Sentenced to 20 Years
description: Joshua Henry Punt, 39, posed online as a teenager and preyed on girls ranging in age from 12 to 16 in states across the country, the federal authorities said.
content: A man in Washington State who posed as a teenager online and blackmailed girls as young as 12 across the country to send him sexually explicit photos and videos was sentenced on Monday to 20 years in prison, the federal authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Bradfield
title: Humanity Is Stupid, Helpless and Possibly Worth Saving
description: Two new editions of the Polish writer Stanislaw Lem’s work showcase his singular imagination.
content: THE TRUTH AND OTHER STORIESBy Stanislaw LemTranslated by Antonia Lloyd-Jones
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone and Ian Austen
title: Canada Doubles Its Afghan Refugee Resettlement Target to 40,000 People
description: The official announcement was made by Canada’s foreign minister on Monday evening, speaking at the United Nations General Assembly.
content: Canada has doubled to 40,000 the number of Afghans fleeing the Taliban that it plans to take in, the Canadian foreign minister said Monday, fulfilling a campaign pledge made by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn
title: SoCal Gas will pay up to $1.8 billion to settle claims from the nation’s biggest gas leak.
description: The natural gas leak, in 2015, forced thousands of people from their homes in an area of Los Angeles.
content: Southern California Gas and its parent company, Sempra Energy, have agreed to pay up to $1.8 billion as part of a settlement agreement announced on Monday related to the nation’s biggest natural gas leak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Marilyn Golden, Effective Voice for the Disabled, Dies at 67
description: “Radicalized” after an accident left her disabled, she became a “linchpin” in the fight for the Americans With Disabilities Act as a leading policy analyst.
content: Marilyn Golden was a college student on a summer backpacking trip in Switzerland when she fell from a tree after a rotting limb snapped. Her back was broken. She spent two years of rehabilitation at Houston Medical Center and had used a wheelchair ever since.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Conversation Is Great Foreplay’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: The Holiday Inn clerk smirked when we checked in early without luggage. He had no clue that after 14 years of marriage and two children, we were in crisis: My wife stating, “I’m not getting my needs met”; our dramatic loss of income; my unwelcome dreams of living separately. No, this was not a tryst but 12 hours of conversation, a conjugal encounter centered on what we wanted and didn’t want from our union. Sure, we made love; conversation is great foreplay. We discovered that the more we communicated, the better the lovemaking. We’ve been married now for more than 50 years. — Tom Willging
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: For Flagging Amazon Games Unit, New World ‘Has to Be Our Breakthrough’
description: The tech giant has struggled to produce popular games, but a much-delayed title released this week could be the first step in a turnaround.
content: Amazon has been successful in nearly every industry it has entered, from books and grocery shopping to cloud computing and movie streaming. So it has been puzzling to many that success in the lucrative video game business has eluded the tech giant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malia Wollan
title: How to Fill a Pothole
description: Choose an off-peak traffic hour. Fill it up slightly higher than the road surface to avoid sag.
content: “Get some orange cones and safety vests first,” says Mike Warren, 31, who was commuting by bike around Indianapolis, trying to finish his degree in computer science, when he decided he had had enough of the city’s pockmarked streets. He had popped tires and bent wheels; neighbors had damaged the undersides of their cars. He called the city to complain, but nothing changed. So Warren and a friend started watching YouTube tutorials on how to fix potholes. They spent about $150 on cones, vests, thick leather gloves, 50-pound bags of cold-patch asphalt repair material, a long-handled steel tamper, a shovel and a broom. They called themselves Open Source Roads. “Like with open-source code, you can make your own modifications,” Warren says.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Do Democrats Have the Courage of Liz Cheney?
description: When one party in our two-party system goes completely rogue, it falls on the other party to protect democracy.
content: A few months ago I had the chance to have a long conversation with Wyoming Representative Liz Cheney. While we disagreed on many policy issues, I could not have been more impressed with her unflinching argument that Donald Trump represented an unprecedented threat to American democracy. I was also struck by her commitment to risk her re-election, all the issues she cares about, and even physical harm, to not only vote for Trump’s impeachment but also help lead the House investigation of the Jan. 6 insurrection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Congress, Vaccine Mandates, Baseball: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Hess
title: How Lip-Syncing Got Real
description: Not long ago, lip-syncing was the domain of subversive drag queens, or pop stars that the media saw as talentless. Now it’s how scrappy amateurs get famous.
content: For several weeks, Netflix has been insisting that I watch its gender-swapped remake of the ’90s teen romantic comedy “She’s All That.” This version — naturally, “He’s All That” — stars Tanner Buchanan as the high school outcast who needs to be whipped into prom-king shape and Addison Rae as the popular girl who does the whipping. It is Rae’s first movie, but she is ubiquitous on TikTok, where her central mode of performance is breezily dancing and lip-syncing to clips of rap songs and ephemeral bits of internet video. When I finally relented and cued up Netflix, I realized that I’d never heard her actual voice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Obama Breaks Ground on Presidential Center in Chicago After Lengthy Discord
description: The project has been bogged down by legal challenges and a federal review. Barack Obama’s presidential papers won’t actually be housed there — they’ll be digitized, another point of contention.
content: More than four years after leaving office, Barack Obama broke ground on Tuesday on his presidential center on the South Side of Chicago, a legacy project that has been bogged down by a lengthy discord over its use of a public park and its potential impact on a historically neglected part of the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Sue Thompson, Who Sang of ‘Norman’ and Sad Movies, Dies at 96
description: She started out a country singer, but she found fame and pop-chart success in the early 1960s with catchy novelty songs, as well as the occasional ballad.
content: Sue Thompson, who after more than a decade of moderate success as a country singer found pop stardom in the early 1960s with hook-laden novelty hits like “Sad Movies (Make Me Cry)” and “Norman,” died on Thursday at the home of her daughter and caregiver, Julie Jennings, in Pahrump, Nev. She was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman and Joseph Goldstein
title: Thousands of N.Y. Health Care Workers Get Vaccinated Ahead of Deadline
description: Though many hospital and nursing home employees remain unvaccinated, officials say worst-case staffing shortages seem less likely.
content: New York State’s pioneering effort to force health care workers to receive coronavirus vaccines appears to have pressured thousands of holdouts to receive last-minute shots, though hospitals and nursing homes continue to brace for potential staffing shortages should the mandate fall short, according to state and industry officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: McKenzie suggests the U.S. may not be able to prevent Al Qaeda and ISIS from rebuilding in Afghanistan.
description: Gen. Kenneth F. McKenzie Jr., the head of the military’s Central Command, was somewhat more pessimistic than other top Pentagon officials testifying before a Senate panel.
content: The top U.S. military commander in the Middle East expressed reservations about whether the United States could deny Al Qaeda and the Islamic State the ability to use Afghanistan as a launchpad for terrorist attacks now that American troops have left the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon and Aanya Wipulasena
title: A Sri Lankan shaman who touted a cure for Covid died after contracting the disease.
description: Eliyantha Lindsay White, who was not vaccinated, claimed to be able to cure coronavirus patients using a holy water.
content: A popular shaman in Sri Lanka who claimed to be able to cure coronavirus patients with a holy water died last week after being infected with the virus, a health ministry official said this weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy and Tiffany May
title: 14 Cuts in 25 Minutes: How Hong Kong Censors Movies
description: The Asian film capital has cracked down on documentaries and independent productions that it fears could glamorize the pro-democracy movement.
content: HONG KONG — The director of “Far From Home,” a short, intimate film about a family caught in the tumult of the 2019 antigovernment protests in Hong Kong, had hoped to show off her work at a local film festival in June.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Tommasini
title: Review: ‘Fire’ Brings a Black Composer to the Met, Finally
description: Terence Blanchard’s fresh, affecting “Fire Shut Up in My Bones” reopened the opera house on Monday after an 18-month closure.
content: On Monday, for the first time in its 138-year history and as it returned from an 18-month closure, the Metropolitan Opera presented a work by a Black composer: Terence Blanchard’s “Fire Shut Up in My Bones.” By opening the season with this work, the Met filled a gaping hole in its repertory at a time when the performing arts are rightfully being challenged to become more diverse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharina Pistor
title: How to Save New York City’s Cabdrivers
description: There's a smart and equitable way to rescue them from their crushing debts.
content: New York City has an opportunity to solve a debt crisis that has devastated a central institution in the lives of many New Yorkers: yellow cabs and their owner-drivers. The solution would come at a relatively modest cost and would help redress an injustice from which the city benefited financially: a creditor-driven bubble in the price of medallions — the permits that allow people to operate cabs — that led many drivers into debt bondage and even prompted some to commit suicide.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Are you still not working because of the pandemic? We want to hear from you.
description: We’re interested in all kinds of stories: people who can’t find work, people who have chosen to take a step back, people who have walked away for good.
content: The economy has begun to rebound from the coronavirus pandemic, but millions of people still haven’t returned to work. Some are looking but haven’t been able to find jobs. Others can’t work because of child care or other responsibilities. Still others say the pandemic led them to rethink how they prioritize their careers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens and Jennifer Schuessler
title: MacArthur Foundation Announces 2021 ‘Genius’ Grant Winners
description: This year’s 25 winners include Ibram X. Kendi, who wrote “How to Be an Antiracist,” the poet Hanif Abdurraqib and the writer and curator Nicole Fleetwood. The awards come with prestige — and $625,000.
content: The historian and social critic Ibram X. Kendi is used to getting hate mail. And sometimes the disdain for him and his work takes the form of a phone call. So when he does not recognize the number he does not often answer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Janet Maslin
title: From Joshua Ferris: A Father’s Scattershot Legacy, Narrated Unreliably
description: Ferris’s new novel, “A Calling for Charlie Barnes,” follows its title character through some 40 jobs, five marriages and assorted children.
content: We first meet Charlie Barnes as he realizes he has “the big kahuna of cancers: pancreatic.” Bad news? It makes his day. He gets on the phone and begins calling everyone who ever slighted him, hoping to make them all sorry. “It’s like priority mail,” he says, that’s how fast it gets you. It kills you so fast you go to the grave like a cannonball. “It’s arguably the worst way anyone can die, with the exception of being hacked to death.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Dasani’s Story
description: Eight years later, we revisit the story of Dasani, a fierce and vulnerable child of New York.
content: Nine years ago, my colleague Andrea Elliott set out to report a series of stories about what it was like to be a homeless child in New York City. As part of her reporting, she soon met a girl in Brooklyn named Dasani — “a spunky 11-year-old with big dreams and no home,” as Andrea has described her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich
title: Japan’s Most Popular Candidate for Prime Minister Is Far From a Shoo-In
description: Taro Kono has by far the highest poll numbers of any candidate to lead the governing Liberal Democrats. But party elders don’t think so highly of him.
content: TOKYO — If popularity were the deciding factor, there would be a clear front-runner to become the next prime minister of Japan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise
title: Amazon announces Astro, a home robot that it swears is more than Alexa on wheels.
description: Astro has a large screen and cameras attached to a wheeled base that can navigate a home. It was part of the company’s annual devices event, where Amazon unveiled an array of product.
content: “Customers don’t just want Alexa on wheels,” Dave Limp, the head of Amazon’s devices, said at a company event on Tuesday. Then he proceeded to introduce a technology-packed home robot that looked a lot like … Alexa on wheels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Lakin
title: Jim Jarmusch’s Collages Are Ready for Their Close-Up
description: The filmmaker has been quietly making small, eerie collages on newsprint for 20 years, with faces switched onto other bodies. Now they’re finally on view.
content: Jim Jarmusch likes removing the heads. He likes to swap the heads of world leaders with Picassos or Basquiats, or simply excise them entirely, leaving a head-shaped void. A man with a coyote’s head rides in the back of a car, rather dejected. Warhol’s head is a favorite motif: twin Andys in sunglasses standing stoically in a tunnel; Warhol’s head grafted onto a state official striding a tarmac; a man slouched in a chair, one of the artist’s Brillo boxes fixed where his head should be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anahad O'Connor
title: Can Drinking Alcohol Raise Your Heart Rate?
description: Drinking can elevate your pulse, which isn’t a concern for most healthy adults, though those with heart rhythm problems should use caution.
content: My smartwatch shows me that my sleeping heart rate is much higher at night after I’ve had a couple of glasses of wine. It’s normally around 60 beats per minute, but it spikes up to 80 to 100 if I drink more than a glass of wine. Is that normal?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: How the Debt Ceiling Came to Be a Political Cudgel
description: The current fight over raising the debt limit is proving to be another lesson in American political dysfunction.
content: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every Tuesday and Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: Navient, with six million borrowers, asks to stop servicing federal student loans.
description: Navient is the second major federal student loan servicer to ask to get out of the business. FedLoan said in July that it wanted out.
content: A second major federal student loan servicer is calling it quits, a decision that will force the Education Department to transfer the accounts of millions of borrowers just as the government begins to resume collecting payments early next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrea Elliott and Ruth Fremson
title: When Dasani Left Home
description: What happens when trying to escape poverty means separating from your family at 13?
content: The city shrinks from view. Cars pass along the highway. Dasani Coates looks out the window, seeing trees and snowy banks, and then a sign:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: When Old Spoons Make Really Great Necklaces
description: The futurist Marine Serre bends antique silverware to her will on the first night of Paris Fashion Week.
content: Fashion Week is back in full force, and there’s a lot to see. Blink (or scroll too fast on Instagram) and you’ll miss the details: tiny bags, tall shoes, feathered hats, leather capes and diamond dog collars. So as part of a new series, Wow Moment, we’ll spotlight things we saw on the runways that delighted or mystified us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: The fear of Delta, more than rewards or mandates, is motivating Americans to get shots, a survey finds.
description: The poll also found that many of the unvaccinated believe that a push for booster shots shows that the inoculations are not working.
content: The Delta variant of the coronavirus was the leading reason that people decided to get vaccinated against Covid-19 this summer and why most say they will get boosters when eligible, according to the latest monthly survey on vaccine attitudes by the Kaiser Family Foundation, released on Tuesday morning. But the survey indicated that nearly three-quarters of unvaccinated Americans view boosters very differently, saying that the need for them shows that the vaccines are not working.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Fitzgerald
title: It’s Never Too Late to Publish a Debut Book and Score a Netflix Deal
description: Jocelyn Nicole Johnson, at 50, is not the average age of a debut author. But the public school teacher describes herself as a “literary debutante” with the October publication of “My Monticello.”
content: “It’s Never Too Late” is a series that tells the stories of people who decide to pursue their dreams on their own terms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich
title: Why the Governing Party Election Is the Main Event in Japan
description: The country has free elections, opposition parties and, lately, public discontent. So why are the Liberal Democrats nearly assured to remain in power?
content: TOKYO — When people think of preordained elections these days, they tend to look to Russia or Iran or Hong Kong. But in Japan, a parliamentary democracy and the world’s third-largest economy, the same party has governed for all but four years since 1955, and most expect it to win the general election due by the end of November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Leigh Hester
title: This Fjord Shows Even Small Populations Create Giant Microfiber Pollution
description: Researchers found that one tiny Arctic village’s unfiltered sewage produces as much microplastic as the treated waste of more than a million people.
content: Svalbard, a Norwegian archipelago chilling halfway between the Nordic country and the North Pole, is known as much for its rugged beauty as its remoteness. From the village of Longyearbyen, visitors and roughly 2,400 residents can appreciate the stark terrain around the fjord known as Adventfjorden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt
title: In a call with Pelosi after the Capitol riot, Milley agreed that Trump was ‘crazy,’ book says.
description: Two days after Trump supporters stormed the Capitol, Gen. Mark A. Milley spoke to Speaker Nancy Pelosi, who was worried Mr. Trump would lash out with military force.
content: Two days after a mob of Trump supporters stormed the Capitol, Gen. Mark A. Milley spoke to Speaker Nancy Pelosi, who was growing increasingly concerned Mr. Trump would lash out and use military force.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: The race to form Germany’s next government.
content: Despite earning the most votes in Germany’s election over the weekend, Olaf Scholz, the leader of the center-left Social Democrats, is not yet assured of becoming chancellor. Instead of two dominant parties competing to go into coalition with one partner, four midsize parties are jockeying for a place in government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: The casualties of misinformation.
content: For more than a year, misinformation about ivermectin — a drug used to kill parasites in dogs, chickens and other patients — has run rampant across social media, podcasts and talk radio. Proponents claim it’s a treatment for the coronavirus, even as the F.D.A. has warned against its use.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: Alemayehu Eshete, Singer Known as the ‘Abyssinian Elvis,’ Dies at 80
description: He became a swaggering star in the late 1960s, when Addis Ababa experienced a golden age of night life and music. Decades later, he was rediscovered.
content: Alemayehu Eshete, a soulful Ethiopian pop singer widely known as the “Abyssinian Elvis” who became a star in the 1960s when a cultural revolution took hold of Addis Ababa, died on Sept. 2 at a hospital there. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Hass
title: Theater’s New Glass Menageries
description: Some of the most innovative set designers and directors are placing actors within transparent boxes, posing novel aesthetic questions in the process.
content: IN A WORLD filtered through screens, a condition made even more acute during pandemic lockdown, the theater’s most anachronistic thrill would seem to be watching lives unfold before us. The actors may not literally be within our grasp, but the lack of a barrier between them and us, the illusion that we are, for once, actually in the room — the sound of the human voice in anguish or joy, a carafe of water crashing to the floor — has never seemed more stirring and essential.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: The A.C.L.U. Errs on R.B.G.
description: A bad tweet reveals a rift over gender and reproduction.
content: Recently, on the anniversary of Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s death, the American Civil Liberties Union set out to pay tribute to her pro-choice heroism, and ended up making the sort of self-parodic blunder the right salivates over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Stephen Colbert Projects Joe Biden Is Still President
description: The “Late Show” host celebrated the results of an Arizona audit that confirmed Trump’s 2020 loss.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Do You Think You Will Ever Travel to Space?
description: A SpaceX rocket launched the first all-civilian crew into orbit. Do you think spaceflight will one day become as ordinary as air travel?
content: There’s a new space race!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Tough questions for Gen. Milley.
content: Gen. Mark Milley, the most senior U.S. military commander, defended his actions in the final months of the Trump administration and warned of the “very real possibility” that Al Qaeda and ISIS could rebuild in Afghanistan, following the withdrawal of U.S. troops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Oliva, Featuring Tapas, Opens in West Harlem
description: Burgers from the Contra and Wildair team, a less-formal approach for Chikarashi Isso and more restaurant news.
content: This bright, spacious Spanish restaurant featuring tapas is a new addition to West Harlem. It opens in the three-month-old Manhattanville Market food court, part of the Jerome L. Greene Science Center at Columbia University. Like the rest of the market, it’s run by the chef and restaurateur Franklin Becker, who has put Chris Strelnick in charge of Oliva as chef de cuisine. The choices among cured meats include top-of-the-line Ibérico hams. There are also cheeses, and about 30 hot and cold tapas. Most are classics like pan con tomate, potato tortilla, garlic shrimp, meatballs and salt cod croquettes. Somewhat more substantial are plates of chicken with sweet pepper sauce and almonds, squid or octopus with potatoes and peppers, and, serving two, a socarrat, which is crispy paella rice with seafood and aioli. Must-have desserts are churros, crema catalana, and chocolate cream with olive oil, salt and almonds. Most of the wines, ciders and beers and even many spirits on the deep list come from Spain and were assembled by the beverage consultant Eamon Rockey. He has also created the cocktails, often with a Spanish twist including sherry. Seating is on an elevated area on one side of the market, with outdoor tables, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: How the Black Women Around R. Kelly’s Case Feel About His Conviction
description: The case could represent a turning point for the #MeToo movement, which some felt had centered on crimes against white women.
content: The woman was taking a nap when her phone began buzzing — and buzzing, and buzzing: A verdict had been reached in the trial of R. Kelly, one of the biggest names in R&B music.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: What Should I Do With My Portrait of a Slaveholding Ancestor?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how to handle articles of history from a difficult past.
content: My family’s ancestors, the Bibbs, were key figures in the establishment of Alabama. My great-uncle was its territorial governor, appointed by James Monroe, and was elected to the governorship when Alabama entered the union. These ancestors had plantations and owned slaves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: amenable
description: This word has appeared in 86 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Chira
title: At This Renowned English Garden, Getting Your Hands Dirty Is the Point
description: Meadows. Soil composition. Propagation. Staking and composting. Attending the weeklong horticulture class at Great Dixter is like getting a Ph.D. in gardening.
content: We were well into the sixth hour of another 10-hour day, our small band of gardeners laboring to find the tiny nodules on a plant stem, cut the stem just below them, and place it into the pots of soil in front of us, all under the exacting eye of our teacher, Fergus Garrett.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario and Joe Coscarelli
title: After R. Kelly’s Conviction, Can the Music Industry Change?
description: The R&B musician’s guilty verdicts met a muted response in the music business that made him a star, and survivors and activists say the field has a responsibility to do more.
content: When a federal jury in Brooklyn on Monday convicted R. Kelly on racketeering and sex trafficking charges, it was immediately seen as a watershed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Gunman in Capital Gazette Shooting Is Sentenced to Multiple Life Terms
description: Jarrod W. Ramos had pleaded guilty to murder charges in one of the deadliest attacks on American journalists. In July, a jury found him criminally responsible for the 2018 shooting in Maryland’s capital.
content: The man who stormed into the newsroom of a community newspaper chain in Maryland’s capital in 2018, killing five staff members, was sentenced on Tuesday to five consecutive life terms without the possibility of parole, according to prosecutors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Instagram Is Adult Entertainment
description: We can’t make social media safe for teenagers. So we should keep them off.
content: The rise of big tech and social media presents a series of difficult, perhaps intractable problems for Western societies. Our internet behemoths are effectively immense media companies pretending to be neutral platforms, feasting on the revenue that once sustained the old media ecosystem while disclaiming normal forms of editorial responsibility. Their key products are agents of decentralized suspicion, generating information overload and feeding both populist paranoia and centrist hysteria. Meanwhile, their leaders run transnational pseudo-governments, exerting traditional political powers — cultural censorship, political banishment, the structuring of vast marketplaces — without clear lines of political accountability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Are you dealing with social anxiety?
description: If you’re finding it difficult to socialize again, we’d love to hear from you.
content: As we head into fall, some of us will look back fondly on our “post-vax” summer as a time of outings with friends, family reunions, or a return to dating from the isolation of Covid-19 restrictions. But the last few months have come with an unexpected downside: social anxiety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: Side effects from a third vaccine dose are similar to those from the second, a C.D.C. report finds.
description: The finding came from a study of Americans who got their third vaccine dose in August and September, and provided a reassuring sign about the safety of additional doses.
content: Americans who received a third dose of a coronavirus vaccine in recent weeks reported side effects at roughly the same rates as they had after their second shots, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on Tuesday, a reassuring sign about the safety of additional doses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Friskics-Warren
title: Bob Moore, an Architect of the Nashville Sound, Dies at 88
description: He played bass on thousands of popular recordings, helping to create the uncluttered style that came to characterize the country music of the 1950s and ’60s.
content: NASHVILLE — Bob Moore, an architect of the Nashville Sound of the 1950s and ’60s who played bass on thousands of popular recordings, including Elvis Presley’s “Return to Sender” and Patsy Cline’s “Crazy,” died on Sept. 22 at a hospital here. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Rachel Quester, Lynsea Garrison, Paige Cowett, Lisa Chow, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop and Chris Wood
title: A Conversation With an Afghan General
description: We speak to a leader in the old administration’s forces about why he thinks the Taliban won and why he left in the middle of the fight.
content: This episode contains strong language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Ozy’s board starts an investigation after a Times report raises questions about the company.
description: The New York Times’s media columnist, Ben Smith, reported that Ozy’s chief operating officer had apparently impersonated a YouTube executive during a conference call with Goldman Sachs bankers.
content: The board of directors of Ozy, a digital media company, said on Tuesday that it had hired a law firm to investigate its “business activities” after a New York Times report raised questions about the company’s practices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Richard Powers on What We Can Learn from Trees
description: The Pulitzer Prize-winning author asks whether we can reimagine our relationship with the natural world before it’s too late.
content: There are certain conversations I fear trying to fit into a description. There’s just more to them than I’m going to be able to convey. This is one of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Bayrakdarian
title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.
content: $2.95 MILLION
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Four Jagged Puzzle Pieces and a Few Weeks for Democrats to Assemble Them
description: The party must keep the government funded, stave off a default, push a $1 trillion infrastructure bill to President Biden and secure the votes for a defining climate change and social policy bill.
content: WASHINGTON — In a pivotal week, in a make-or-break stretch for President Biden’s domestic agenda, congressional Democrats are trying to assemble a puzzle of four jagged pieces that may or may not fit together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: For Transgender Youth, Stigma Is Just One Barrier to Health Care
description: Discrimination, delays and systemic hurdles prevent young trans people from reaching the care they need, a new study finds.
content: Piper, a 17-year-old transgender girl, says she knows she is fortunate.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Richard Powers
description: Powers transcript
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Richard Powers. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Stephanie Grisham’s Book Details Trump’s ‘Terrifying’ Temper
description: The former press secretary is reflective in her tell-all: “I should have spoken up more.”
content: WASHINGTON — Stephanie Grisham, the former Trump White House press secretary perhaps best known for never holding a televised briefing with reporters, plans to release a tell-all book next week that accuses President Donald J. Trump of abusing his staff, placating dictators like Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, and making sexual comments about a young White House aide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: Bolsonaro’s wife was vaccinated during their visit to New York for the U.N.G.A.
description: The president of Brazil began his visit by defying a U.N. honor system requiring proof of vaccination, and four members of his entourage have tested positive.
content: Jair Bolsonaro, Brazil’s proudly unvaccinated president, is contending with more fallout from his visit to New York last week to speak at the United Nations: A fourth member of his entourage has tested positive for Covid-19, and his wife, Michelle, opted to get vaccinated before they returned home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson, Michael Forsythe and Cao Li
title: China and Evergrande Ascended Together. Now One Is About to Fall.
description: The property giant’s success mirrored the country’s transformation from an agrarian economy to one that embraced capitalism. Its struggles offer a glimpse of a new financial future.
content: HONG KONG — Xu Jiayin was China’s richest man, a symbol of the country’s economic rise who helped transform poverty-stricken villages into urbanized metropolises for the fledgling middle class. As his company, China Evergrande Group, became one of the country’s largest property developers, he amassed the trappings of the elite, with trips to Paris to taste rare French wines, a million-dollar yacht, private jets and access to some of the most powerful people in Beijing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Stocks tumble in worst day since May, as tech shares slide and bond yields climb.
description: Investors, weighing the prospect of the Federal Reserve preparing to reduce its purchases of government debt, sold off bonds, pushing the 10-year’s yield to its highest level since June.
content: The prospect of the Federal Reserve not reaching as deep into its bottomless pockets is starting to hit home for investors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Jumaane Williams May Challenge Gov. Hochul in Democratic Litmus Test
description: Mr. Williams, the New York City public advocate, would offer Democratic voters a clear left-leaning alternative to Ms. Hochul, a centrist from western New York.
content: Jumaane D. Williams, the left-wing New York City public advocate, announced an exploratory committee for governor on Tuesday, the most substantive sign yet that next year’s primary may become a vigorous battle over the direction of New York’s Democratic Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper
title: Top defense officials acknowledge they advised against withdrawing all troops from Afghanistan.
description: Tuesday’s appearance by Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III, Gen. Mark A. Milley and Gen. Kenneth F. McKenzie, Jr. was the start of back-to-back Senate and House hearings.
content: Top U.S. military officers acknowledged publicly for the first time that they had advised President Biden not to withdraw all American troops from Afghanistan ahead of the chaotic evacuation during which 13 American service members were killed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Powering Down
description: Are you able to “unplug?”
content: Even before the events of the last year and a half, many struggled to tear themselves away from their computers, phones and other screens — and simply relax.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: Mastercard will provide a buy-now, pay-later option to lenders.
description: The payment processor moves in on a part of the industry crowded with upstarts.
content: The buy-now, pay-later services that let shoppers settle up for their purchases in four interest-free installments have so far been the domain of start-ups. But now a traditional financial player is moving in with an option of its own: Mastercard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan O'Callaghan
title: This May Be the First Planet Found Orbiting 3 Stars at Once
description: It’s called a circumtriple planet, and evidence that one exists suggests that planet formation is less unusual than once believed.
content: GW Ori is a star system 1,300 light years from Earth in the constellation of Orion. It is surrounded by a huge disk of dust and gas, a common feature of young star systems that are forming planets. But fascinatingly, it is a system with not one star, but three.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein
title: Back to High School,After Missing So Much
description: Students missed homecoming, field trips and classes, while also handling anxiety and economic precarity. Now, they must leap into the future, with the school’s help.
content: WATERBURY, Conn. — This fall, there is a surreal swirl of newness and oldness in the hallways of John F. Kennedy High School: Black Lives Matter face masks and exhortations to pull them up — “Over your nose, please!” — but also ribbing and laughter, bells ringing, hall passes being checked and loudspeaker reminders about the dress code (collared black or navy shirts and khaki or black bottoms).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt
title: Milley reassured a top Chinese general that Trump would not attack, a recent book says.
description: “Things may look unsteady,” Gen. Mark A. Milley reportedly told the Chinese general two days after President Trump’s supporters stormed the Capitol. “But that’s the nature of democracy.”
content: Gen. Mark A. Milley, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, called his Chinese counterpart in the final months of the Trump administration to reassure him that Donald J. Trump had no plans to attack China and that the United States was not collapsing, according to “Peril,” a recently released book by the Washington Post reporters Bob Woodward and Robert Costa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Manchin and Sinema Should Just Say No
description: Don’t let the Democrats spend themselves into oblivion.
content: Dear Senators Manchin and Sinema,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: Milley defends his actions at the end of Trump’s term, saying top officials knew of his calls to China.
description: “My loyalty to this nation, its people, and the Constitution hasn’t changed and will never change as long as I have a breath to give,” Gen. Mark A. Milley said.
content: Gen. Mark A. Milley, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, defended his actions in the tumultuous last months of the Trump administration, insisting that calls to his Chinese counterpart and a meeting in which he told generals to alert him if the president tried to launch a nuclear weapon were all part of his job duties as the country’s most senior military officer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: Suspect in Atlanta Spa Killings Pleads Not Guilty to 4 Counts of Murder
description: Robert Aaron Long pleaded guilty in July to four other murder charges and will spend the rest of his life behind bars.
content: ATLANTA — A 22-year-old man facing the death penalty for a shooting rampage at a string of spas in the Atlanta area pleaded not guilty to four murder charges on Tuesday, raising the possibility of a protracted court battle over one of the deadliest U.S. mass shootings of 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Oil prices near a three-year high as an energy crunch looms.
description: Analysts say soaring natural gas prices are helping push oil futures higher, as Brent crude briefly topped $80 a barrel.
content: Brent crude, the international oil benchmark, touched $80 a barrel on Tuesday for the first time in nearly three years amid growing signs of an energy crunch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: George Malkemus, Who Pushed Manolos to New Heights, Dies at 67
description: He successfully marketed Manolo Blahnik’s extravagantly heeled confections. Then a television character named Carrie Bradshaw brandished a pair in “Sex and the City.”
content: George Malkemus, the steady, sunny Texan who helped turn the designs of an eccentric shoe designer named Manolo Blahnik into a global empire, and then attempted the same business alchemy with the actress Sarah Jessica Parker for her own shoe brand, died on Sept. 16 at his home in Manhattan. He was 67.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Loses Case to Enforce Omarosa Manigault Newman’s N.D.A.
description: Donald Trump had filed the case against Ms. Manigault Newman, a former White House aide and “Apprentice” star, after she wrote a tell-all book about serving in his administration.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump has lost an effort to enforce a nondisclosure agreement against Omarosa Manigault Newman, a former White House aide and a star on “The Apprentice” who wrote a tell-all book about serving in his administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Lemire
title: Baseball’s Wall Street-Style Executives Get Titles to Match
description: As M.L.B. front offices get more and more corporate, titles have steadily inflated. Yesterday’s general manager is today’s president of baseball operations … or chief baseball officer.
content: The Tampa Bay Rays recently bestowed a new contract and a new title on their baseball operations leader, Erik Neander. He began the season with dueling corporate epaulets — senior vice president of baseball operations and general manager — and is now president of baseball operations. This was not, however, an elevation in rank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: How an 11-Foot-Tall 3-D Printer Is Helping to Create a Community
description: Three-dimensional printing can create nearly any object. A partnership in Mexico is putting that theory to the test, building a village for residents living in poverty.
content: Pedro García Hernández, 48, is a carpenter in the southeastern Mexican state of Tabasco, a rainforest-shrouded region of the country where about half of the residents live below the poverty line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Goodman
title: ‘No Time to Die’: What the Critics Are Saying
description: After a star-studded premiere in London, this much-delayed Bond film is drawing mostly positive early reviews.
content: The latest James Bond adventure, “No Time to Die,” was supposed to hit theaters in April 2020. The pandemic hit instead, and the film’s release was postponed more than once. But on Tuesday the 25th installment in the franchise had a splashy world premiere in London.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: In One Moment, Messi and P.S.G. Make It All Work
description: The Lionel Messi goal that completed a Champions League win over Manchester City offered a flash of his past, and a glimpse of his new club’s future.
content: PARIS — Lionel Messi picked the ball up in that spot, the one that has served as the starting point for so many of his finest moments, the one that he knows so well that it might as well be his spot. It has, for 15 years, been his base camp, his happy place: a few yards inside from the right touchline, a few yards from halfway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anahad O'Connor
title: Can a Low-Carb Diet Help Your Heart Health?
description: Overweight people who ate fewer carbohydrates and increased their fat intake had significant improvements in their cardiovascular disease risk factors.
content: Going on a low-carb diet has long been a popular weight loss strategy. But some doctors and nutrition experts have advised against doing so over fears that it could increase the risk of heart disease, since such diets typically involve eating lots of saturated fats, the kind found in red meat and butter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Facebook Isn’t Scandal-Proof
description: This social network may finally be paying the price for its bad reputation.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: LeBron James said he was vaccinated, after evading questions about his status last season.
description: He also said he would not use his platform to publicly encourage others to be inoculated against Covid.
content: LeBron James, the Los Angeles Lakers star, said on Tuesday that he had been vaccinated against the coronavirus, after evading questions about his vaccination status last season. Several other high-profile N.B.A. players have resisted getting vaccinated before the start of the N.B.A. season next month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Liberals Dig In Against Infrastructure Bill as Party Divisions Persist
description: They doubled down on a promise to oppose the infrastructure bill until Congress acts on a far more expansive domestic policy package.
content: WASHINGTON — Liberal Democrats dug in on Tuesday against voting for a $1 trillion bipartisan infrastructure bill this week, angrily rejecting a decision by Speaker Nancy Pelosi to push the bill forward before the party could resolve bitter disagreements over a sprawling social policy and climate package.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Powell
title: A.C.L.U. Apologizes for Tweet That Altered Quote by Justice Ginsburg
description: The organization acknowledged that changing references from women to people was a mistake — albeit a well-intentioned one.
content: Anthony Romero, the executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union, said Monday that he regretted that a tweet sent out recently by his organization altered the words of a well-known quote by the late Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: In Atlanta, Fear of Violent Crime Creates Opportunity for a Polarizing Politician
description: Kasim Reed, the former mayor whose administration was marked by corruption scandals, is running for another term, promising to restore public safety.
content: ATLANTA — The fear of rising crime in American cities is having a profound effect on mayoral politics from New York to Seattle. In Atlanta, it has had the power of resurrection, delivering a reanimating jolt to the once-moribund career of one of the South’s most polarizing public figures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juan Gabriel Vásquez
title: The Nobel Laureate Wole Soyinka’s First Novel Since 1973
description: “Chronicles From the Land of the Happiest People on Earth” is at once political satire and murder mystery, and a lament for the spirit of his native Nigeria.
content: In the first pages of his poignant 2006 memoir, “You Must Set Forth at Dawn,” Wole Soyinka quotes an old piece of Yoruba wisdom: “As one approaches an elder’s status, one ceases to indulge in battles.” In the 15 years that have since gone by, Soyinka has stubbornly refused that advice. As a political activist, the 87-year-old Nobel Prize winner has never stopped intervening in our public conversation, whether to defend freedom of expression, condemn religious fundamentalism or destroy his American green card after the election of Donald Trump. As a writer, he has produced essays and plays with remarkable regularity, but “Chronicles From the Land of the Happiest People on Earth” is his first novel in 48 years, and only the third in his long career. It is also the ultimate rebellion against the Yoruba dictum, a huge battle of a book, and to read it is to watch in fascination as Soyinka indulges in it.
source.name: The New York Times
